ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

PRIMARY ONE REGISTRATION

(Priority to families with three children or more)

     1.  Er Lee Bee Wah asked the Minister for Education in light of the Government's call for families to have more children, whether the Ministry will review its existing policy on Primary One registration to give priority to those with three children or more as an incentive for parents. 

     The Minister for Education (Dr Ng Eng Hen):   Mr Speaker, Sir, up to the late

Column: 183

1980s, priority admissions into schools for Primary One (P1) were used to support population policies. Following a review, the Government decided in 1992 to de-link P1 registration from population policies, even though they were an effective measure for some schools.

 

     The reason to de-link registration into schools with population policies was guided by this principle that primary school admissions should be determined by educational goals, wherever possible. So if you look at the current criteria, proximity to home is a key criterion for admission so that a young child does not have to travel a long distance to go to school.  Having siblings studying in the same school is another criterion as this is convenient for parents; allows the older sibling to help the younger child and builds school ties. We give priority to key stakeholders, such as the children of old boys or girls, members of the school advisory committees and parent volunteers as it strengthens community and parental support for the schools. 

 

     So the criteria I have listed are primarily driven to meet educational goals and the current scheme reflects a careful balance of the various factors that serve the educational interest of the child and the school.

     Er Lee Bee Wah (Ang Mo Kio):  Thank you, Mr Minister, for the answer. The Minister mentioned just now that it was effective for the population growth and based on the feedback from my residents, they are asking for this to be re-introduced. I hope that the Minister will consider this.

     Dr Ng Eng Hen:   Sir, as I have mentioned, MOE is not keen to link population policies and school admissions. I think this is a better way of doing it. We have done it before where we have linked

Column: 184

it and you get different outcomes. I think our schools should serve primarily the educational goals of the child, and this is what explains our reluctance.

RESEARCH WORK IN UNIVERSITIES


     2.  Mr Zainudin Nordin asked the Minister for Education since research has been identified as a key pillar of our economic advancement (a) what is the progress of our efforts to promote more research work in our universities; (b) how do the universities measure the success of research work; (c) whether the quality of research and the processes that are used to measure it are comparable to world standards; and (d) as research is a knowledge-intensive and time-demanding process, what is the maximum number of research groups that research fund recipients can belong to.

     Dr Ng Eng Hen:  The Government announced its plan to increase its Research and Development (R&D) expenditure from 2.25% of GDP in 2004 to 3% by 2010. As part of this plan, MOE's Academic Research Fund (AcRF) to support research in our universities was nearly tripled to a total sum of about $1.4 billion for five years starting from FY2006 when compared to the preceding same period.
  
     From this, MOE sets aside $250 million for the establishment of Research Centres of Excellence (RCEs) at our universities to fund programmes that will generate research of global impact.  RCEs are co-funded by the National Research Foundation (NRF), which provides another $500 million, making a total of $750 million. Our universities have geared up their research activities and quality, in tandem with the increased funding.  We have already seen some promising indicators of progress. Let me cite some:


     (1) Number of postgraduate research students funded by the AcRF currently

Column: 185

stands at 4,676. This is a 13% increase from 2006 and 65% increase compared to 2001;


     (2) Number of projects funded increased from 30 in 2006 to 53 in 2007, representing an increase in funding from $24 million to $42 million; 


     (3) Three RCEs have been approved over the past two years.  One such RCE is the Centre for Quantum Technology at NUS, where a team of three researchers recently won the prestigious 2008 National Science Award for their outstanding theoretical and experimental studies in the field of quantum cryptography; and

 

     (4) NUS and NTU have improved their performance on the research indicators. This was asked by Mr Zainudin. One such indicator is published by the Times Higher Education Supplement (THES).  In terms of citations per faculty member, NUS has moved up in rank from the 115th-122nd band in 2006, to the 61st-67th rank band in 2007.  NTU too has moved up about 40 places.

 

     With these efforts, our universities are gradually climbing up in terms of international research benchmarks.

 

     Our universities adopt internationally-used indicators like those employed by the THES and the Shanghai Jiao Tong University's Academic Ranking of World Universities.  Besides the number of citations per faculty, other indicators, like the number of high quality publications and the number of patents filed and granted, are used to measure their progress.

 

     Beyond quantitative measures, the MOE and the universities rely on qualitative assessments by experts and international academic leaders. For example, the Academic Research Council (ARC) was formed in June 2006 and is

Column: 186

chaired now by Dr Robert Brown who is President of Boston University and former Provost of MIT. 

 

     MOE does not cap the number of research groups that research fund recipients can belong to. This was the specific question asked by the Member. However, when assessing research proposals for funding, expert and evaluation panels do take into account the ability of the researcher to provide the level of commitment needed for the success of the project.

     Mr Zainudin Nordin (Bishan-Toa Payoh):   Thank you, Mr Minister, for the comprehensive reply. May I know the success of NUS and NTU and the other universities to encourage our local talents and students to take up research? What is the progress so far?

     Dr Ng Eng Hen:   Sir, the overall view for the universities, the NRF, the Research Innovation and Enterprise Council (RIEC) chaired by the Prime Minister is to build an environment where there are avenues and opportunities for researchers. At the same time, we also recognise that if you want to jump-start the system, if you want to climb ahead, you will have to bring in people who have already been investing their time and energy into research. Otherwise, you have to re-learn the cycle and you are not very steep in your learning curve.

 

     I think that would be the major thrust of our efforts. I think we have succeeded. Members would have read of luminaries and very strong academics who have been persuaded by our environment to re-locate here and many of them, for example, are in the prime of their research careers. Recently, NTU started another Research Centre of Excellence (RCE) on earth observatory, and a whole team of expert volcanologists who are experts in earth quakes, chose to site here from Stamford. Even though, we are near the

Column: 187

ring of fire, we do not have volcanoes in Singapore, but yet they chose to site here. So that is one indication of the success that we have.

 

     This will create the environment where Singaporean researchers will benefit. They will be exposed to scientists and researchers of high calibre, whose work is at the cutting edge, and they will, in turn, also take on many of the roles. Many of our own local scientists have indeed gained world recognition.

GRAND THEFT AUTO IV


(Approval for sale)

     3.  Mr Christopher de Souza asked the Minister for Information, Communications and the Arts (a) why was Grand Theft Auto IV, a computer game that allows players to simulate driving drunk, stealing cars, dealing in drugs, visiting strip clubs, robbing ladies and knocking down pedestrians, allowed by the Media Development Authority (MDA) to be sold in Singapore; and (b) how does MDA's approval for the sale of the game align with the concerted efforts of Ministry of Home Affairs to encourage Singaporeans of all ages to stay clear of crime, drugs and gangsterism.

     The Senior Minister of State for Information, Communications and the Arts (RAdm [NS] Lui Tuck Yew) (for the Minister for Information, Communications and the Arts):  Mr Speaker, Sir, Media Development Authority (MDA) launched Video Games Classification in April this year to allow more choice for adult gamers while according the appropriate level of protection for the young. The ratings and content advisory allow parents to make informed choices about the video games available in the market. At the same time, MDA has put in place enforcement measures and has also

Column: 188

embarked on public education initiatives to promote the broader theme of gaming wellness while raising awareness of the classification system.

 

     Under the Video Games Classification system, the game Grand Theft Auto IV was released with an M18 rating, that is, it is restricted for sale to those who are 18 years and above. When rating the game, the MDA took careful consideration of the content, themes and storyline found in the game, recognising that adults are better equipped to discern fact from fiction.

 

     The rating given to the game is in line with that in other countries which have similar rating systems. In the US, the game was rated "Mature", indicating that the game is meant for those 17 and above. The UK and Europe gave the game an 18 rating, while in Australia the game was given their highest rating of MA15+.  It is also rated 18 in Japan.

 

     Local retailers are required to check the age of customers at the point of sale. The MDA has ensured that video game retailers comply with the age restriction by conducting checks on the retailers and distributing the classification guidelines to the retailers.

 

     With regard to public education, MDA has been reaching out to gamers, children, parents and game retailers through publicity materials and the media to educate the public about the classification system, and to address parents' concerns about video games. They are also working with industry and community to reach out to the public through major events such as the World Cyber Championships that were held here in August.

 

     In summary, recognising that game contents do at times contain mature themes, MDA has put in place a classification system, enforcement mea

Column: 189

sures and public education initiatives to encourage responsible and healthy gaming in Singapore. Parents with young children should also exercise judgment when they purchase games for their children.

     Mr Christopher de Souza (Holland-Bukit Timah):  Thank you, Minister, for the reply. Does the Minister appreciate that the M18 rating is largely artificial, given that students or children under 18 can easily access the voluminous number of copies already in the market? If so, the question ought really to be whether this game should enter the market in the first place?

     RAdm [NS] Lui Tuck Yew:  I think what we have in place is an enforcement measure to try and prevent retailers from, first of all, selling games to those who are underaged. I recognise that the games that are already available may be passed from friend to friend. But part of the process, I think, is in educating gamers as well as the general public of the need to take appropriate measures, including parents, so that they are mindful of the activities that their children are into, as well as a cyber wellness programme to help educate our children about the overall impact of playing such games.

     Mr Christopher de Souza:  Sir, it says on the MDA website that the feedback mechanism includes interested parties like gaming industry key players and gamers themselves. Would not a more objective feedback mechanism include, say, people who deal with youth crime, like Deputy Public Prosecutors and Community Court Judges, to see the real effect, if any, of the game on offenders' propensity to commit crime?

     RAdm [NS] Lui Tuck Yew:   We certainly welcome feedback from all interested parties. We have been monitoring the reaction to Grand Auto Theft IV. So far, there has been no reaction from our gaming community, as well as from the

Column: 190

larger public, to the introduction of this game into Singapore.

FREE-TO-AIR SPORTS CHANNELS


     4.  Miss Penny Low asked the Minister for Information, Communications and the Arts in view of the upcoming Youth Olympic Games and our national agenda to cultivate the spirit of a sporting nation (a) whether he will consider having free-to-air sports channels; (b) if so, whether they will cover a wide spectrum of sports; and (c) if not, why.

     The Minister for Information, Communications and the Arts (Dr Lee Boon Yang):  Mr Speaker, Sir, I thank the Member for her interest in a Free-to-Air (or FTA) sports channel as a means of cultivating the spirit of a sporting nation.

 

     In January 2000, MediaCorp (or TCS as it was known then) had launched an FTA sports channel called Sportscity. Members may not have remembered this, it is almost eight years ago, but actually they did launch a sports channel. This sports channel offered a range of sports content from local to international to instructional sports programmes.  However, the channel was not commercially viable and incurred substantial losses due to low viewership, high content acquisition fees and the focus by advertisers on selected major sporting events rather than generic sports programming.  The channel was revamped into City TV in 2001, with sports contents reduced to 60%. That also did not survive beyond a year.

 

 


     Sir, the cost of operating a free-to-air sports channel is substantial and the bulk of the cost goes towards content acquisition and production costs.  In particular, the cost of sports content has increased sharply.  According to MDA, for major popular sports content such as football, the acquisition cost can go up to several hundred million dollars.  For an FTA channel, such costs would have to

Column: 191

be met in one of two ways or both: first, advertising and sponsorship revenues, and secondly, radio and television licence fees. 

 

     Sportscity has shown that commercial viability of an FTA sports channel based on advertising and sponsorship alone is difficult to achieve.  To sustain an FTA channel that covers a wide range of sporting programmes, radio and TV licence fee would have to be increased significantly.  This increase in radio and television licence fee would impact on all consumers, regardless of their individual viewing preference, in fact, regardless of whether they watch sports or not.  This approach is not in the best interests of viewers and the general public.

 

     Sir, instead, the sporting interests of consumers are being met on two fronts.  First, for key sporting events of national significance, the Media Development Authority (MDA) ensures that all Singaporeans' and all consumers' interests are served by requiring these events to be made available for free-to-air television, so that everyone can watch these programmes.  These include the recent Olympic Games and Southeast Asian Games.   I would like to take the opportunity to assure Ms Low that the 2010 Youth Olympics will be a sports event that will receive free-to-air television coverage.

 

     Secondly, for other sporting events, the needs of the consumers are better met with commercially viable, dedicated pay-TV channels so that consumers need only pay for what they want to watch and not be burdened with the high cost of a general free-to-air sports channel.

Column: 191

DISCRIMINATION AGAINST MOTHERS-TO-BE IN WORKPLACE

     5.  Mdm Ho Geok Choo asked the Acting Minister for Manpower whether

Column: 192

workplace harassment laws can be put in place to prevent employers from discriminating against mothers-to-be in the workplace as part of measures encouraging more women to work. 

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Acting Minister for Manpower (Mr Hawazi Daipi) (for the Acting Minister for Manpower):  Sir, workplace laws are already in place to protect pregnant employees.  Under the Employment Act, dismissal on the grounds of pregnancy is an offence.  It is also an offence to terminate the employment of an employee when she is on maternity leave.    

 

     As part of the enhanced Marriage and Parenthood package, we have strengthened the protection for pregnant employees.  After October 2008, when the legislative amendments take effect, employers will be required to pay employees their maternity leave benefits if the employees are dismissed without sufficient cause within the last six months of pregnancy or retrenched within the last three months.


     Should employees feel harassed or discriminated against at the workplace, they should take up their complaints directly with their management, or through their unions if they are union members.  Employees may also lodge a complaint directly with MOM and we will investigate the complaint and provide advice on the appropriate courses of action.
 
     However, we cannot rely on legislation alone to address workplace harassment and discrimination effectively.  We must also positively shape employers' mindsets so that they recognise the importance of fair treatment of all employees, including mothers-to-be.  This would also benefit employers in attracting and retaining valued employees.  In this regard, the Tripartite Alliance on Fair Employment Practices (or TAFEP) has been actively

Column: 193

promoting the adoption of fair employment practices among employers and working closely with them to put in place progressive and non-discriminatory HR practices.

     Mr Zaqy Mohamad (Hong Kah):   It seems that the MOM defines some mothers-to-be as pregnant for more than six months and above.  Would the MOM consider putting in an anti-harassment law for prospective mothers – young, married women, for example – who are applying for jobs or are working and are being asked by employers if they are planning to start a family or having more children?  I think this should also be considered as potential harassment tactics by employers.

 

     Mr Hawazi Daipi:  Sir, hiring and firing is subject to agreement of both the employer and employee in general. 

 

     In the case of hiring pregnant women, again, it is subject to the needs of the employers.  However, if employees have reason to believe that they are not employed because they are pregnant, they can lodge a complaint to MOM so that MOM can give appropriate advice to the prospective employee on the course of action to be taken.  But, what is important is to change the mindsets of employers, in general, of the importance of treating not just their workers but potential workers well.  In an environment of shortage of Singaporean workers, it makes sense for the employers to be the employers of choice and to do that they  must be willing to take good care of their employees, including pregnant women and potential employees who are pregnant.

     Mr Zaqy Mohamad:  Just to clarify my comment.  When I said "prospective mothers-to-be" I meant young mothers who are thinking of either having children or have children and planning to have

Column: 194

more, rather than prospective employees of a company.

     Mr Hawazi Daipi:  Sir, I thought I answered that question.  Prospective employees who are pregnant. 

     Mr Zaqy Mohamad:  Young mothers who are planning to have children, for example, and today you find that some are complaining that employers are asking them, "Are you planning to have a family?"  I think that is quite discriminatory.

     Mr Hawazi Daipi:   I said that if they believe that this is discriminatory and they do not like it, they can come to MOM to lodge a complaint and we will give them appropriate advice.  But, generally, it is really up to the employees.  In the first place, they are already called for interviews.  For someone who has applied for a job and called for interview, there must be a good chance to be considered for the job.  Whether or not there is a law to prevent employers from picking those who are not likely to be planning to be pregnant or to have a baby, or whether or not they want to practise fair employment practices, they may not even call this prospective employee for interview.  So, no laws can actually protect any potential employee, whether or not they want to plan to have a baby or not in future.

INVESTIGATION INTO COMPLAINT BY FOREIGN DOMESTIC WORKER


     6.  Mr Lim Biow Chuan asked the Acting Minister for Manpower (a) what is the average time taken to complete an investigation into a complaint lodged by a foreign domestic worker against her employer; and (b) whether the employer under investigation can employ another foreign domestic worker in the meantime.

     Mr Hawazi Daipi (for the Acting Minister for Manpower):  Sir, when a complaint is lodged by a foreign domestic

Column: 195

worker (FDW) against her employer, MOM will first assess the case to see if an investigation is warranted. 

 

     In some cases, the complaint arises from a misunderstanding between the employer and the foreign domestic worker.  In these situations, MOM would assist to clarify and mediate between the two parties. There would then be no need for an investigation.  In 2007, about 35% of the nearly 2,100 complaints made were resolved at this stage. 

 

     Where the facts reveal that an offence may have been committed, MOM will proceed to carry out an investigation.  The duration of investigation into each case depends on its complexity and the level of cooperation given by the various parties involved.  It is important to ensure investigations are carried out thoroughly.  For the cases investigated in 2007, about 81% were completed within 90 days or three months. 

 

     If investigations reveal evidence that the employer is likely to have committed an offence, he will be blacklisted from employing another FDW.  This is necessary to protect other FDWs from falling victim to errant employers.

     Mr Lim Biow Chuan (Marine Parade):  Sir, I just want to clarify with the Senior Parliamentary Secretary.  In the meantime, whilst investigations are being carried out, is the employer allowed to employ another foreign domestic worker?

     Mr Hawazi Daipi:  Sir, that depends on the nature of the complaint.  If the complaint involves abuses and rather serious, we will not allow the foreign domestic worker's employer to employ another domestic worker while investigations are still ongoing.  But in some

Column: 196

cases where it involves possible misunderstanding, we may consider.

     Mr Lim Biow Chuan:   Sir, again just to clarify.  Last month, the Law Minister had reiterated the principle that all are innocent until proven guilty.  By taking such administrative action to prohibit an employer from employing a foreign domestic worker whilst the case is being investigated, would this not go against the principle that the employer should be deemed innocent until he is proven guilty?  Has MOM considered that the administrative action in prohibiting the employer would be unfair to employers with young children or with elderly parents who may need a foreign domestic worker urgently and who may be innocent of the complaint by the foreign domestic worker?

     Mr Hawazi Daipi:  Sir, I do remember the Minister for Law saying that, but I also remember him saying that those who are not charged or have not been found guilty may not necessarily be innocent. 

 

     Generally, Sir, the Ministry looks into all cases of FDW's complaints and where the complaints suggest there are breaches of the work permit conditions by the employer, a thorough investigation would be undertaken.  All complaints by FDWs are dealt with objectively and when a prima facie case has been established for serious breaches, such as physical abuses, ill treatment, non payment of salaries or illegal deployment of foreign domestic worker, the employer will not be allowed to employ a new foreign domestic worker pending the outcome of MOM's investigations.  This is a precautionary measure to prevent another FDW from being subject to the same abuse while investigations are ongoing. 

 

     Similarly, when an FDW is under investigation for complaints against her, she will not be placed with another employer while investigations are ongoing.

AUDITING OF STATUTORY BOARDS BY AUDITOR-GENERAL


     7.  Mr Gautam Banerjee asked the Minister for Finance in view of the increased focus on corporate governance and transparency (a) whether it is sufficient for large statutory boards to be audited by the Auditor-General only once in every five years; and (b) how does this practice compare with other countries such as the UK, Australia, Canada and New Zealand.

 

     8.  Mr Gautam Banerjee asked the Minister for Finance which statutory boards is the Auditor-General unable to audit under the current legal framework and whether this framework will be amended to allow the Auditor-General to audit all statutory boards.


 

     The Senior Minister of State for Finance (Mrs Lim Hwee Hua) (for the Minister for Finance):  Mr Speaker, Sir, may I have your permission to take Question Nos. 7 and 8 together?

     Mr Speaker:  Yes.

     Mrs Lim Hwee Hua:  Sir, let me inform the House that statutory boards are audited annually, whether by the Auditor-General or a public accounting firm.  Since last year, the Auditor-General's plan has been to audit the larger statutory boards at least once in five years.  This does not mean that the larger statutory boards cannot be audited by the AG more frequently.  For example, the AG audits IRAS every year.  Likewise, the Monetary Authority of Singapore is audited by the AG every year as the MAS Act requires it.  My Ministry has supported a higher manpower budget to enable his office to increase the frequency of his audit of statutory boards.

 

     Mr Banerjee asked about the practice in other countries such as Australia, New Zealand, Canada and UK with regard to

Column: 198

the audit of statutory boards. In these four countries, the accounts of the bodies equivalent to our statutory boards are by law required to be audited by their national audit institutions annually.

 

     The current system of the Auditor-General coming in periodically to audit a statutory board, in between audits by a public accounting firm appointed in consultation with the AG, has served us well.  As I mentioned, the AG will subject a statutory board to more frequent audits where necessary.  This is a more focused and practical approach as it allows him to direct resources towards areas which are of greater significance.

 

     As regards Mr Banerjee's other question, under the current legal framework, the Auditor-General is empowered to initiate and carry out an audit of a statutory board only if the Act creating that statutory board so provides. The Bunker Convention

     21.   Mr Zaqy Mohamad asked the Minister for Transport what measures does the Ministry have in place to monitor and minimise noise pollution from ageing MRT tracks and trains, especially those that are in close proximity to residential housing.

     Second, the engineering design of the MRT tracks helps to minimise noise.  Our MRT tracks are ballasted tracks with timber sleepers, which provide cushioning whenever the steel wheels of trains come into contact with the steel rail of the tracks.  This system also reduces noise that travel through the track by dampening vibrations that may propagate through the track structure.

     Fourth, LTA has worked together with SMRT to measure the noise generated by trains at selected locations close to major residential estates every three months.  Where the noise levels are close to the noise emission limits, SMRT will carry out preventive maintenance.

 

     In our densely built-up urbanised landscape, it is inevitable that MRT tracks are sometimes built close to residential housing.  LTA will try to minimise noise as much as possible, but some degree of noise is unavoidable, and we ask for public understanding of the matter.
